A cube has edges of length 1 cm and has a dot marked in the centre of the top face.  The cube is sitting on a flat table.  The cube is rolled, without lifting or slipping, in one direction so that at least two of its vertices are always touching the table.  The cube is rolled until the dot is again on the top face.  The length, in centimeters, of the path followed by the dot is $c\pi$, where $c$ is a constant.  What is $c$?
inference:
The cube has edges of length 1 cm.  The dot is in the center of the top face.
When the cube rolls, the dot moves along the surface of the cube.
The path followed by the dot is a portion of a circle.
To find the circumference of the circle traced by the dot, we need to find the diameter of the circle.
The diameter is the length of the diagonal of a face.
The diagonal of a face has length $\sqrt{1^2 + 1^2} = \sqrt{2}$ cm.
The circumference of the circle is $\pi \times \text{diameter} = \pi \sqrt{2}$ cm.
The cube rolls until the dot is again on the top face.
The cube has 6 faces.
When the dot is on the top face, the cube is positioned on the table with the top face facing up.
The dot is in the center of the top face.
To bring the dot back to the top face, the cube has to make one full rotation.
In one full rotation, the dot moves along a portion of a circle with a circumference of $C = \pi \sqrt{2}$ cm.
The cube has to rotate until the dot is back on top. The dot has moved along a distance equal to the circumference of the circle, which is $C = \pi \sqrt{2}$.
The length of the path followed by the dot is $\pi \sqrt{2}$.
The problem states that the path followed by the dot is $c\pi$, so $c\pi = \pi \sqrt{2}$.  Thus, $c = \sqrt{2}$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{\sqrt{2}}$
